passages.text: The Emerging Markets Weekly

As the summer draws to a close, we think the global backdrop remains generally favourable for EM assets. EM CBs may feel encouraged to continue with cautious easing, while the USD has been constrained by US policy and politics. We focus on curve shapes and update our supply forecasts in EM credit.
Weekly Markets View Falling into step 2

EM Credit, Rates, FX. 12 In EM credit we recommend a switch from KAZAKS long-end bonds into \(\) 2032\(/\) \ \(2037\) . In contrast, we recommend an extension trade from 2033s into 2047s on the NGERIA curve. In EM FX, we recently initiated a long CNY CFETS trade idea.
Data Reviews & Previews Asia, Latam & EEMEA. 14

This document is intended for institutional investors and is not subject to all of the independence and disclosure standards applicable to debt research reports prepared for retail investors under U.S. FINRA Rule 2242. Barclays trades the securities covered in this report for its own account and on a discretionary basis on behalf of certain clients. Such trading interests may be contrary to the recommendations offered in this report.
Please see analyst certifications and important disclosures beginning on page 23. Completed: 29- Aug- 25, 00:39 GMT Released: 29- Aug- 25, 00:43 GMT Restricted - External

As the summer draws to a close, we think the global backdrop remains generally favourable for EM assets. EM CBs may feel encouraged to continue with cautious easing, while the USD has been constrained by US policy and politics. We focus on curve shapes and update our supply forecasts in EM credit.

The recent steepening of the UST curve has led to meaningful flattening of EM spread curves. This, we think, provides some tactical opportunities where curves have deviated from the broader trend or where the flattening has been excessive.

We update our country- by- country EM sovereign credit supply expectations ahead of the autumn primary season. We expect c.USD35- 40bn in additional gross supply from EM sovereigns over September- December, which brings our new full- year 2025 forecast to USD185- 190bn.

EM FX/Local Rates have performed well this year and could see some further near- term resilience amid a restrained USD and lower US rates. Moreover, a relatively muted hit to growth from US trade tariffs so far suggests a more benign backdrop. Relatively light leveraged investor positioning suggests scope for further upside. Separately, hopes of more stimulus measures in China, the effect of the anti- involution campaign and CNY stability are providing an anchor for EM, especially Asian FX.

Our EUR/USD forecast path implies that EM currencies will continue to be supported over the near term, but may face gradual depreciation pressures in the months ahead. In this respect, EMEA FX have the most exposure to any EUR/USD depreciation while Asia may be least affected. Similarly, this implies EM LC yields are unlikely to see any sharp reversal higher in the near term, but any USD recovery further out could help fuel some turnaround in EM yields.

After dovish signals from the Fed, we now expect US rate cuts to begin in September, with further easing likely into 2026. EM central banks—including Mexico and the Philippines—are also lowering rates, while Korea and Hungary are holding for now. Additional cuts are anticipated from Malaysia and Poland if economic data weaken. Globally, central banks appear to be more comfortable shifting toward a more accommodative stance.

Recent global developments include new investments and tariffs following the US- Korea summit, Mexico aligning trade policy with US concerns, steep tariffs threatening India's exports, and rising financial and political pressures in South Africa, Russia, Brazil, and Venezuela, highlighting ongoing international tensions and economic uncertainty.

- Israel plans a final Gaza offensive while facing political challenges. Taiwan's nuclear referendum failed due to war turnout, pressuring the ruling party. Argentina deals with a corruption scandal before midterms, and right-wing candidates lead in Chile's run-off polls.- Brazil plans to present its 2026 budget without new revenue measures, aiming for a small surplus through existing proposals. In Colombia, disagreements over the 2026 budget may force the government to pass it by decree, likely resulting in spending cuts.

The dovish tilt by Fed Chair Powell at Jackson Hole and President Trump's effort to fire Fed Governor Lisa Cook1 have driven a steepening of the US Treasury curve. While the door has been opened further for a September Fed rate cut, concerns about Fed independence are weighing on rates at the long end2.

The recent steepening of the US curve is of course not a new phenomenon. In fact, the US Treasury curve has steepened steadily since January of this year. However, in the April- June period, UST curve steepening was accompanied by (bull- )steepening of EM spread curves in the aftermath of the 'Liberation Day' sell- off, especially in EM HY. In contrast, the recent leg of UST curve steepening has led to a meaningful flattening of EM spread curves (Figure 1), which have now reverted to their usual negative correlation with the US rates curve. For the Asian credit market specifically, we discussed this in Asia Credit Strategy: Spread curve dislocations, 26 August 2025, but this has been a phenomenon across EM regions, and including EM HY and IG sovereigns (Figure 2). Naturally, such sharp curve moves can provide opportunities for tactical trades to optimise exposure along specific curves that have deviated from the broader trend or where the flattening has been excessive. We explore this theme in our Top Trade recommendations section this week.
FIGURE 1. Contrary to the April-June period, UST curve steepening has led to meaningful EM spread curve flattening recently...
FIGURE 2. ...with sizable moves across EM HY and EM IG sovereigns
Median of 23 EM USD sovereign curves across IG and HY. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
Median of 15 EM HY sovereign and 8 EM IG sovereign curves. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

As the summer draws to a close, investor attention tends to turn to the autumn primary market season. So far this year, EM sovereigns have issued c.USD150bn in USD/EUR hard- currency bonds (including Mexico's PCAPs), with heavy issuance particularly in January/February and more recently in June and July (Figure 3). YTD issuance by EM sovereigns is already higher than our original USD125- 130bn forecast for 2025 (see 2025 EM sovereign supply outlook, 5 November 2024). Our updated country- by- country supply forecasts for the remainder of 2025 (Figure 4) add another USD35- 40bn to annual issuance, which raises our 2025 full- year forecast to USD185- 190bn.

However, we think it is unlikely that 2025 supply will beat the 2020 record, when EM sovereign supply exceeded USD200bn amid very low global interest rates and high fiscal financing needs as a consequence of the COVID pandemic. High yields in a historical context, and the fact that many issuers have used the favourable market conditions earlier this year to front- load issuance, are likely to constrain primary market activity in the autumn season. That said, we expect sizable supply from select LatAm countries (Colombia in particular, following the revision of the country's deficit targets and issuance plans in June and potential pre- financing of 2026 needs) and Asian IG issuers. In EEMEA, we notably expect select HY countries with upcoming maturities (Nigeria, Egypt, South Africa) to return to markets, should conditions be supportive.

From a broader market perspective, we do not think that supply will be disruptive over the next few months. In fact, our forecast of USD35- 40bn in new gross supply for the rest of this year is matched by scheduled interest payments and principal redemptions of the same magnitude.
FIGURE 3. We now expect full-year 2025 EM sovereign credit supply to reach c.USD185-190bn...
USD and EUR-denominated bonds, including Mexico PCAPs. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
FIGURE 4. ...with USD35-40bn in new gross supply likely to come over September-December
Source: Barclays Research

As investors return from their summer holidays they will find that the picture remains largely similar to the start of summer. The USD remains under pressure and despite attempts at recovery, growing expectations of Fed easing as well as President Trump's ongoing criticism of Fed policy and, in particular, concerns about Fed independence continue to restrain the

currency. Indeed, Trump's effort to fire Fed Governor Cook and her refusal to be dismissed mark a further escalation of the battle between him and the Fed. To the extent that this weighs on the USD, EM FX could benefit in the short term.

At the Jackson Hole meeting, Fed Chair Powell opened the door wider for a September rate cut amid a shift in tone over the US jobs market. Our economists now expect the Fed to ease in September 2025 followed by quarterly reductions through June 2026 to reach a terminal rate of \(3.25 - 3.50\%\) . However, a September rate cut is not a foregone conclusion, with key data releases such as the next employment report, preliminary benchmark revisions and CPI providing further colour on the state of the economy. Even so, US rates markets are unlikely to turn hawkish anytime soon. As such, EM FX and local rates should benefit from a subdued US rates outlook.

Against this backdrop, EM assets have performed strongly this year, particularly EM equities. The outlook for EM FX and local rates remains constructive in our view. Despite tariff implementation, global growth has not fallen off a cliff. Even in the biggest exporting region, namely Asia, exports are holding up for now. While this could be due to trade re- direction, transshipments and front- loading, the picture has not worsened dramatically so far in H2. While there are some risks of moderation over the remainder of the year, a significant hit to EM growth now looks less likely this year.
FIGURE 5. EM assets have fared well YTD, especially equities
Note: Index rebased to 100 on January 1,2025.
FIGURE 6. Hedge fund positioning in EM FX/local currency still relatively light
Note: Chart depicts rolling 2 year correlations between HF performance and underlying assets. Source: HFRI, Bloomberg, Barclays Research
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

Despite the rally in EM assets, positioning remains underweight. Our proxy of hedge fund EM positioning in FX and local rates appears to show that positioning actually lightened up earlier in the year, perhaps due to worries about tariffs, but is now starting to turn around. Fund flows have also been positive (see Summer of inflows). Given that positioning, at least among leveraged investors, is relatively light, there could be scope for the current rally in EM FX/local to gather further momentum.

A constrained USD and rangebound US rates backdrop continue to provide tailwinds to EM assets. Overall, a more dovish Fed could reduce hedge costs further, which, in turn, could drive further upside in EURUSD. We explore how this could impact EM FX and rates below. However,

as we noted in Dollar and the US slowdown, we remain cautious about extrapolating current trends into extended excess dollar weakness. Even on the rates front, markets have already priced in just over 50bp of Fed easing this year, in line with our US economists' view. This suggests that much is in the price already. Nonetheless, a reversal appears unlikely at this stage, which ought to be supportive for EM FX and rates.

Some easing in US- China tensions and a stable to firmer CNY should provide further support to EM assets, particularly in Asia, with the CNY acting as an anchor for regional FX. We previously discussed how the PBoC has become more comfortable with mild CNY appreciation versus USD, and over recent days the PBoC has continued to fix the CNY stronger. As our economists point out, there are rising expectations of official Chinese policy support over the weeks ahead, the geopolitical backdrop has improved amid easing tensions with the US, the anti- involution campaign is set to extend through H2 and liquidity is being channelled into the domestic equity market. Despite weaker data in July, China's economic outlook is unlikely to deteriorate markedly while the CNY continues to show few signs of depreciation pressures.
FIGURE 7. Some softening in China growth momentum points to further incremental stimulus
FIGURE 8. CNY acting as an anchor for many EM currencies
Note: Our China high frequency tracker is composed of various monthly China activity and sentiment indicators. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
Note: Chart depicts regression betas of CNYUSD returns versus XXXUSD returns over 12m and 5y periods. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

Examining the various drivers (ie, S&P 500, UST 10y yields, EURUSD) of the performance of EM FX versus USD since the start of the year reveals that the biggest determinant has been the move in EURUSD. That said, several EM currencies have gained more against the USD than our model would suggest, which implies some positive idiosyncratic factors also driving performance. This is particularly apparent for some LatAm currencies (BRL and MXN). In contrast, most Asian currencies have underperformed our model's predictions (except TWD and MYR). As we detailed in Asia FX: Limits to FX Intervention, a few central banks, including those of China, India and Taiwan, may have attempted to limit FX gains via intervention, though most in Asia did not.

As such, our forecast path of EUR/ \(1.17\) (near term) declining to 1.13 (12 months out) implies that EM currencies will continue to be supported over the near term but may face gradual depreciation pressures further out. In this respect, we think EMEA FX has the most exposure to any EURUSD depreciation while Asia may be least impacted. Separately, it's worth highlighting that gyrations in US 10y Treasury yields have had only a marginal impact on EM FX this year, with Asian currencies once again least impacted. We will be watching developments with respect to risks to the Fed's independence to provide further clues on direction, but assuming
that the bulk of USD pressure is behind us, we think near-term EM FX resilience could give way to depreciation further out.

We undertake a similar exercise for EM local currency bonds but add in the US ISM as a cyclical macro variable. We also find that FX (EUR versus USD) has an outsized impact on movements in local bond yields, with the largest impact seen in LatAm bonds whereas Asia is far less impacted. Moves in US stocks also seem to have some impact on EM yields but to a lesser extent. Assuming that the USD remains under some pressure in the short term, this implies EM LC yields are unlikely to see any sharp reversal higher but any USD recovery further out could result in some turnaround in EM yields.
FIGURE 9. EURUSD drives most of the move in EM FX YTD.
FIGURE 10. EURUSD moves also play a part in explaining moves in EM LC yields.

Note: The figure depicts the decomposition of moves in EM FX versus USD YTD. We regress daily XXXUSD returns on UST10 yields, EURUSD, and S&P 500 to generate regression betas. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

Note: The figure depicts decomposition of monthly moves in EM 10y yields YTD. We regress monthly changes in EM 10y yields on US ISM Manufacturing, USDEUR, and S&P 500 on a five year look-back to generate betas. Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

The dovish winds of Wyoming. After Federal Reserve Chair Powell made dovish comments at the Jackson Hole symposium last week, market participants have turned more optimistic. His remarks suggested the Fed may cut interest rates as early as September, focusing more on the challenges facing the job market than on short- term inflation from tariffs. As a result, our US economics team now expects the Fed to restart its rate cut cycle sooner. They forecast a 25bp cut in September, followed by another 25bp in December. This would bring the federal funds rate to a range of 3.75- 4.00% by the end of 2025. Looking ahead to 2026, the team anticipates two more 25bp cuts, in March and June, which would lower the rate to 3.25- 3.50% by the end of that year (US Outlook: September cut is the baseline, but the door is ajar).

A weak jobs report in the US next week could intensify market pricing for an easing stance. Our US economics team anticipates an increase of 75K in nonfarm payroll employment for August, which is generally in line with July's gain of 73K. Given recent fluctuations in government payrolls, our house view is to place greater emphasis on the private payroll figures, which could rise by 75K, compared to an 83K increase in July. If there are no revisions, our house view suggests that headline employment will have grown by an average of 54K over the three months ending in August, marking a slowdown from the 99K average during the previous
three- month period ending in May (US Economics August employment preview: Moving sideways).

A more comfortable easing path ahead in EM. While we have not changed our monetary policy outlook for emerging markets—except for the central bank of Mexico—we anticipate that the likely less restrictive conditions in US short- term rates will enable EM central banks to cautiously continue easing. For the central bank of Mexico, we now believe Banxico will deliver a domestically- driven 25bp rate cut in September, but we added a 25bp rate cut in November, to keep the fed funds- reference rate spread at 300bp, followed by 25bp cuts in December this year, as well as in March and June next year, to leave the reference rate at \(6.50\%\) before year- end 2026.

BSP cut rates... This week, the central bank of the Philippines (BSP) cut its policy rate by another 25bp to \(5.00\%\) , as widely expected, likely on the basis of benign CPI inflation. In the press conference following the release of the policy statement, BSP Governor Eli Remolona Jr revealed that the central bank thinks it could be near the end of its easing cycle – but indicated that there is perhaps room for one more 25bp rate cut. Overall, we maintain our base case of another 25bp rate cut in October, though the risk is of a delay if the BSP decides to wait for more data to assess how rice prices are reacting to the government's decision to halt rice imports for 60 days from 1 September. However, even if another 25bp rate cut materializes, this would leave the policy rate at a still relatively high \(4.75\%\) – which implies the risk of further normalization via even more rate cuts if CPI inflation does turn out to be more benign than the BSP expects.

...while the BoK and the NBH paused... The central bank of Korea (BoK) opted for a dovish pause, maintaining its policy rate at \(2.5\%\) . This decision marked a shift from the BoK's earlier pattern of quarterly rate cuts, as it chose to wait for further stabilization in housing price momentum. Nonetheless, the BoK governor extended forward guidance for the easing cycle through the first half of 2026. We believe the threshold for avoiding further easing in 2026 remains high, and we continue to anticipate additional rate cuts in October 2025 and February 2026. The central bank of Hungary (NBH) also kept its policy rate steady at \(6.5\%\) , expecting inflation to stay above target through 2025 and only return to \(3\%\) in early 2027. Citing strong consumption, volatile prices, and wage growth, the central bank emphasized the need for tight policy and signaled rates will likely stay on hold. However, we continue to expect the NBH to deliver a total of 50bp cuts in the last two meetings of the year.

...and we expect rate cuts in Malaysia and Poland. Looking ahead, we have the interest rate decisions of the central banks of Malaysia (BNM) and Poland (NBP) scheduled for next week. While we do anticipate another 25bp rate cut from Bank Negara Malaysia—and acknowledged that it could come at next week's meeting—our baseline expectation is that the central bank will hold off for now, waiting until the release of the Q3 GDP advance estimate in October. If Q3 GDP growth comes in below \(4\%\) y/y as we expect, it is likely the central bank will implement a rate cut in November. We also expect the NBP to cut the reference rate by 25bp to \(4.75\%\) , along with consensus. There were no interest rate decisions in Latin America this week, and no regular monetary policy meetings are scheduled for next week.

Market participants await Banxico's Quarterly Report. Banco de México's upcoming Quarterly Report, rescheduled to Friday due to Centennial celebrations, is expected to focus on three main areas: (1) Insights from the press conference and Q&A, especially regarding how many additional rate cuts the board or a majority may pursue, with attention on whether post- September cuts will align with the Fed or be independent; (2) forecast adjustments, where inflation projections are likely to remain unchanged despite recent positive trends attributable to favorable base effects, while growth projections for 2025 (currently at \(0.1\%\) ) could be revised upward; and (3) the release of the 2026 monetary policy meetings calendar.

Successful US- Korea summit while Mexico continues to align with US incentives. Korea's President Lee held a summit with President Trump on 25 August, and guided for increased defense spending and more investments in the US. Subsequently, Korean businesses struck 11 MOUs in the areas of shipbuilding, energy, defense, and Al. Both sides committed to a \(15\%\) tariff from July 31 and mitigated downside risks. Meanwhile, Mexico is planning to introduce new and higher tariffs on Chinese imports as part of its upcoming budget proposal for FY26, mainly to address US concerns about Chinese goods entering the American market via Mexico. Other recent measures include significant tariffs on online purchases and textiles from China, as well as enforcement actions against the sale of illegal goods. Although it is uncertain whether the US will push for an early revision of the USMCA trade agreement, we expect that Mexico will maintain a solid trade framework and continue to benefit from nearshoring trends.

BRICS under fire. In contrast, India will face \(50\%\) tariffs on exports to the US starting 27 August, making it one of the highest tariffed countries. This poses downside risks as India is put on a disadvantageous position vs peers. We estimate \(70\%\) (USD55bn) of India's exports to the US are now under serious threat, hitting 'gems and jewelry', 'textiles, apparels and leather' and 'electronics (excluding smartphones)'. As trade talks between India and US have stalled, the Indian administration is readying itself to roll out measures to support the economy at large and exporters in particular to tackle the US import tariffs (see India- US tariff update: When worst fears come true).

SWIFT risks. Besides tariff negotiations between the US government and South Africa, we highlight the rising risk of financial sanctions. Local press headlines on Tuesday reported that the National Treasury had in fact met with some of the country's large banks last Friday to discuss a scenario where the country was suspended from the SWIFT system. The central bank of South Africa (SARB) has since Wednesday downplayed such fears, indicating that any restrictions on access to the global SWIFT system are more likely to affect individuals rather than South Africa as a whole, and that sanctions applied by major jurisdictions, are typically targeted at named individuals, entities or activities - not at countries or their core financial market infrastructure. It concluded that at present, there is no indication that South Africa's membership in SWIFT, or its access to other international payment systems, are at risk.

'Economic war'. Shifting gears to Russia- Ukraine, US President Trump warned that there would be an 'economic war' that would be bad for Russia if the fighting continues, and that he was mulling severe economic sanctions on Russia if it rejects the ceasefire talks. But as we have highlighted in last week's outlook, the prospects of imminent bilateral or trilateral talks between the leaders appears relatively remote, given the lack of convergence in the respective interests of both sides. Trump had said that he would like to arrange a bilateral meeting between Putin and Zelenskiy and a trilateral between himself, Putin and Zelenskiy within 2- 3 weeks. Separately, in Brazil, the Supreme Court is scheduled to start Bolsonaro's trial on Tuesday, 2 September (he is accused of participating in an attempted coup after his defeat in the presidential elections of October 2022). The procedure is expected to conclude by the 12th, and if the former president is found guilty, it could result in a sentence of 12 to 43 years in prison. Increased headlines on the topic could escalate tensions between the US and Brazilian authorities, as discussed in Brazil: Facing a bric(k) wall.

US moves Navy vessels close to Venezuelan shoreline. The United States has ordered the deployment of additional military assets to international waters near Venezuela's coast. As we discussed in our recent note, Flirting with the military option, reports say that the USS Lake Erie, a guided missile cruiser, and the USS Newport News, a nuclear- powered fast attack submarine, will arrive in the region early next week9. The sources declined to detail the specific mission of the deployments but have said that recent movements are aimed at addressing threats to US national security from specially designated "narco- terrorist organizations" in the region. These forces will join the three destroyers (USS San Antonio, USS Iwo Jima and USS Fort Lauderdale), which are expected near Curacao, just 40 miles away from the Venezuelan coast. Considering the additional assets, that total deployment of troops would increase to 8,500.

In our view, the incremental pressure from these events could be an attempt by the US to drive divisions within the Maduro regime to foster a political transition, but the path remains uncertain. A full- scale US invasion of Venezuela does not seem the most likely scenario but given that military intervention in some form has remained a topic of discussion, it leaves open the potential for some sort of targeted actions. The success of the pressure strategy seems likely to depend at least partly on whether the threats against the regime are seen as credible.

Israel's final push into Gaza City Looms. On Tuesday, Prime Minister Netanyahu indicated that he would convene a meeting with Israel's top decision- making body to discuss prospects for a deal to wind down the war in Gaza10. He indicated that an evacuation of Gaza City is inevitable, and that Hamas will be given until mid- September to agree to a ceasefire leading to the return of the remaining Israeli hostages and the dismantling of its government and weapons. Bloomberg also has reported that Israel's army is preparing for a final push into Gaza City, with troops and tanks having already encircled the city11.

Taiwan nuclear plan referendum. Taiwan held a referendum on August 23 on whether it should keep its third nuclear power plant, contingent on the authority's confirmation of its safety. This was initiated by the opposition party and was seen as pushing against the current ruling party's agenda for more renewable energy. While the voting outcome showed 74% of voters are in favor of keeping the nuclear power plant, the referendum was invalid as the total number of votes was lower than the threshold for 25% of eligible population. In addition, there was also voting for the recall of seven opposition lawmakers, but this was rejected in all districts. This broadly puts pressure on the ruling party politically12.

Argentina - Most recent corruption scandal shakes local markets. Attention has been focused on a corruption scandal. Last week, voice recordings of Diego Spagnuolo denouncing a corruption scheme were made public. Spagnuolo was head of the national disability agency (designated by Milei). The recordings reveal a private conversation where Spagnuolo reports a bribing scheme between the agency and a medical supplier. Spagnuolo mentions Karina Milei as a beneficiary of the scheme. After the recordings were made public, Milei removed Spagnuolo from the agency. Local newspapers have followed the issue closely, and have questioned whether it will affect Milei's LLA in the upcoming midterms13.

Right wing keeps its lead in Chile. Right-wing candidate Kast continues to lead in the Cadem poll14 and appears better positioned for a run- off. Kast's voting intention ticked down 1pp to 28% this week, while Jara's (left) rose 2pp to 27%. So the three right-leaning candidates, Kast+Matthei+Kaiser, add up 49% (unchanged from last week). For the second round, the survey shows Kast as the most competitive candidate, at 44% in a run-off with Jara (31%, with 25% undecided), while Matthei polls at 40% versus 33% for Jara and 27% undecided.

New budget, old tools. In Brazil, the 2026 budget (PLOA) is due to be presented to Congress this Friday, August 29. MoF Haddad said earlier this week that no new revenue measures would be introduced, suggesting that the government will rely on those already presented, such as the IOF tax increase, Provisional Measure 1303 (to be debated in the coming weeks), as well as SOE dividends, oil auctions, tax renegotiations, and possibly a reduction in tax credits. Per the budget guidelines bill (PLDO) presented in April, next year's primary balance target is a surplus of BRL34.3bn (or 0.25% of GDP). However, excluding BRL55.1bn in precartario payments not subject to the rules, the government can present a primary deficit of BRL20.8bn and technically still be in compliance with the center of the target. Our working assumption is that the 2026 PLOA will make ends meet, at least on paper, and show a 0.25% primary surplus, dependent on a significant increase in revenue (see more details in Brazil: A fiscal onion).

Persistent budget discussions. Differences over the 2026 budget persist in Colombia. Legislators are demanding the government to cut the budget by 7.2% (COP39.5trn). Given the resistance is the legislature, the most likely outcome is that Congress does not approve the budget and, similar to last year, the government would have to pass it by decree. Nonetheless, in that scenario the government might be forced to cut the budget by at least COP26.3trn, which they had expected to get from a new tax reform that does not have congressional support either. Although the budget discussion could generate some noise, we are of the view that the effect would be limited given that this is a transitional budget that would mainly serve for H1- 26, and the new administration is likely modify it for H2- 26.
Top Trade Recommendations

In EM credit we recommend a switch from KAZAKS long- end bonds into \(\) 2032\(s /\) \ \(2037\) s. In contrast, we recommend an extension trade from 2033s into 2047s on the NGERIA curve. In EM FX, we recently initiated a long CNY CFETS trade idea.
EM CreditSwitch from KAZAKS \(2044s /\) \(2045s\) into \(\) 2032s / \(2037s\) Andreas Kolbe

EM CreditSwitch from KAZAKS \(2044s /\) \(2045s\) into \(\) 2032s / \(2037s\) Andreas KolbeIn the Weekly Markets View section, we discuss how the recent steepening of the UST curve has led to a meaningful flattening of EM USD spread curves, especially among EM IG sovereigns. The KAZAKS curve is a case in point. While spreads of the KAZAKS 2032s and 2037s have not moved much since the bonds were issued in late June, those at the long end of the curve (KAZAKS 2044s/2045s) have tightened considerably (Figure 1). This has left the curve very flat, with the 2032s and 2037s screening as cheap. And while Kazakhstan's fundamental trajectory remains on solid footing, as evidenced by S&P's decision to revise the country's BBB- rating outlook to positive last weekend, we think that spreads at the long end provide little buffer against potential further volatility in rates. Hence, we think that shortening duration makes sense.

Switch from NGERIA 2033s into 2047sAndreas KolbeConversely, we recommend extending duration on the NGERIA curve. Contrary to the broader trend, the spread curve between NGERIA 2047s and NGERIA 2033s has flattened only marginally recently and remains at very steep levels in a historical context, resulting in a very meaningful yield difference between the two bonds (Figure 2). As also highlighted in the Weekly Markets View section, we think it is possible that Nigeria will return to markets over the next few months, but given the steep yield curve and the overall high level of yields, we would expect any such issuance to be focused on the 5- 10y sector. We rate Nigeria sovereign credit OW and think that an extension into the long end makes sense at current levels.
FIGURE 1. The KAZAKS spread curve has flattened meaningfully; 2032s and 2037s screen as cheap on the USD curve
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
FIGURE 2. Conversely, the NGERIA curve has largely escaped the flattening trend; we think an extension trade makes sense
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research

We recently recommended going long CNY CFETS at 96.35, targeting 99.1, stop loss 94.98. China has allowed the CNY and CFETS to strengthen, despite a relatively flat USD, amid a further trade truce with the US. China is sending a message with recent CNY strength and confidence amid resilient exports performance. Sentiment towards Chinese equities has turned increasingly positive and South Bound stock connect flows have accelerated over recent weeks. We think the PBoC will maintain a relatively firm bias for CNY in a controlled manner in the short term and prefer to reflect this via a long CNY CFETS trade idea, rather than outright short USDCNH, due to adverse carry costs. We continue to think that a significant CNY rally against the USD would require tailwinds from DXY softness.
Data Reviews & Previews
A review of key data points in the past week and a preview of data releases and market- moving events in the week ahead, including Barclays forecasts.
- EM Asia Data Review & Preview- Emerging Europe, Middle East and Africa Data Review & Preview- Latin America Data Review & Preview

Review of last week's data releases

Friday, 29 AugustPeriodPrev 2Prev 1LatestForecastConsensus07:00 Korea: Industrial production, % y/yJul5.1-0.31.63.33.909:00 Philippines: Trade balance, USD bnJul-4.0-3.6-4.0-4.3-4.309:00 Philippines: Total exports, % y/yJul7.615.526.111.410.509:00 Philippines: Total imports, % y/yJul-2.5-1.110.81.00.615:00 Thailand: Current account, USD bnJul-1.5-0.32.42.01.018:30 India: GDP, % y/yQ25.66.47.46.66.7

Korea: We estimate that IP growth rose to \(3.3\%\) y/y in July, from \(1.6\%\) in June. We believe a pickup in auto output and a further increase in semiconductor production, along with more working days, drove an increase in IP growth. Philippines: An unfavourable base likely pulled both export and import growth down in July. The subsiding of export front-loading likely resulted in a slightly wider trade deficit.
Thailand: The current account surplus likely moderated in July m/m, driven by a smaller merchandise trade surplus.
India: While moderating from \(7.4\%\) in Q1, we estimate Q2 GDP growth was a resilient \(6.6\%\) y/y, supported by an uptick in agriculture output and largely steady services growth.
Sunday, 31 AugustPeriodPrev 2Prev 1LatestForecastConsensus09:30 China: NBS manufacturing PMI, indexAug49.549.749.349.549.5

China: Despite the tariff pause extension on 11 August, we think recent capacity cuts amid the anti- involution push will weigh on production, as will preparations for the 3 September military parade. We expect the manufacturing PMI to stay in contraction for a fifth month, at 49.5 in August versus 49.3 previously.

Monday, 01 SepPeriodPrev 2Prev 1LatestForecastConsensus08:00 Korea: Trade Balance, USD bnAug6.99.16.66.5-08:00 Korea: Exports, % y/yAug-1.34.45.81.2-08:00 Korea: Imports, % y/yAug-5.33.30.7-4.2-08:30 Korea: S&amp;P Global manufacturing PMI, indexAug47.748.748.0--08:30 Taiwan: S&amp;P Global manufacturing PMI, indexAug48.647.246.2--09:45 China: RatingDog manufacturing PMI, indexAug48.350.449.549.749.7

12:00Indonesia: Trade balance, USD mnJul158.84301.54103.53461.8-12:00Indonesia: Exports, % y/yJul5.39.711.35.21.212:00Indonesia: Imports, % y/yJul21.14.14.3-7.4-12:00Indonesia: CPI, % y/yAug1.61.92.42.42.412:00Indonesia: Core CPI, % y/yAug2.42.42.32.32.313:00India: "Final" S&P Global manufacturing PMI, indexAug58.459.159.8--

Korea: We expect August exports to increase by 1.2% y/y (Jul: +5.9%) as tech exports continue to hold up. We believe strength in semiconductor exports continues, while the key focus is likely to be on the resilience of non-tech exports. Imports are likely to show a dip, which points to the trade surplus remaining relatively wide at USD6.5bn.
China: We expect some boost from the tariff pause extension to the RatingDog manufacturing index, which surveys more export-oriented firms,helping the print to hold up at 49.7 in August.
Indonesia: With export front-loading likely waning, we believe the trade surplus narrowed in July. CPI inflation was likely broadly stable in August.
Tuesday, 02 SepPeriodPrev 2Prev 1LatestForecastConsensus
07:00 Korea: CPI, % y/y

Korea: We expect inflation to fall to 1.7% y/y in August, from 2.1% in July. We believe the 50% discount on user fees from a large telecom operator likely reduced headline inflation by 50-60bp. That said, we think higher fruit prices and continued rises in vegetable prices present a risk to our forecast. Oil prices being flat on month also suggests that inflation may be slightly higher, about 1.7%, in our view. We expect core inflation to fall to 1.5% y/y.
Wednesday, 03 SepPeriodPrev 2Prev 1LatestForecastConsensus07:00Korea: GDP 2nd release, sa, % q/q (y/y)Q20.1 (1.1)-0.2 (0.0)0.6 (0.5)0.7 (0.6)
Korea: We expect small revision higher in second release of Q2 GDP data, with exports seeing a nudge up and modest improvements in services production.

Thursday, 04 SepPeriodPrev 2Prev 1LatestForecastConsensus-Thailand: CPI, % y/yAug-0.6-0.2-0.7-0.8-Thailand: Core CPI, % y/yAug1.11.10.80.807:00Korea: Current account balance, USD bnJul5.710.114.37.815:00Malaysia: Overnight rate, %Sep3.003.002.752.75
Thailand: We expect headline CPI inflation to turn more negative in August on continued drops in international energy prices, while core inflation is likely to be stable at subdued levels.

Korea: We expect the CA surplus to remain wide at USD7.8bn in July, versus USD14.3bn in June, which was a record high, boosted by a solid goods surplus and a notable increase in primary income surplus.

Malaysia: While we expect another 25bp rate cut from Bank Negara Malaysia - and note a risk that this is delivered at the upcoming September meeting - our base case is for the central bank to stay on hold for now until the Q3 GDP advance estimate is released in October. Should Q3 GDP growth fall under 4% y/y as we expect, the central bank will likely deliver a rate cut in November.
Friday, 05 SepPeriodPrev 2Prev 1LatestForecastConsensus09:00Philippines: CPI, % y/yAug1.31.30.91.116:00Taiwan: CPI, % y/yAug1.61.41.51.6
Philippines: A smaller decline in retail fuel prices likely led to a slightly higher CPI inflation reading in August. The core measure likely edged up as well to 2.5% y/y from 2.3% in July.

Taiwan: We expect August CPI inflation to increase to 1.6% y/y (Jul: +1.5%), with core inflation also increasing to 1.8% y/y from 1.7% in July. We believe heavy rainfall in August likely nudged up vegetable prices in the month.
Note: Bloomberg consensus forecasts and release dates are subject to change.
Source: Bloomberg, Barclays Research
Zalina Alborova, Barclays, UK | Ercan Erguzel, Barclays, UK | Michael Kafe, Barclays, UK

Main indicatorsPeriodPreviousBarclaysActualCommentsMexico: Current account balance, USD bnQ2-7.611.280.2The sizable difference between our forecast and the observed print was 50% due to theaccumulative effect of past data revisions and50% due to the significant outflow of dividendsand royalty payments that usually happens in Q1. All in all, exports have shown resiliency amidimposed US tariffs and USMCA uncertainties,while the current account balance continues to be small and well-financed by FDI and portfolioflows.Brazil: Current account balance, USD mnJul-5331--7067The rolling 12-month deficit widened toUSD75.3bn (3.5% of GDP), from USD73.3bn (3.4%) in June and USD30.7bn (1.4%) a year earlier,driven by higher imports and a growing deficit inservices and profit remittances abroad.Brazil: IPCA-15 inflation, % m/mAug0.33-0.28-0.14A one-off discount to electricity bills explained the monthly deflation, which should be reversed inSeptember. Monday 01 SepPeriodPrev-3Prev-2Prev-1ForecastConsensus- Colombia: Current Account, $ mnQ2-1572.4-2258.8-2290.5-2724.0-08:30 Chile: Economic activity, % y/yJul2.93.33.1--11:00 Peru: CPI inflation, % m/mAug-0.060.130.230.21-11:00 Mexico: Remittances, $ bnJul4.85.45.24.9-Tuesday 02 SepPeriodPrev-3Prev-2Prev-1ForecastConsensus08:00 Brazil: GDP, % y/yQ243.62.92.1-

Brazil GDP: We estimate that the Brazilian economy grew 0.3% q/q (2.1% y/y) in Q2 25, decelerating from 1.4% q/q (2.9% y/y) in Q1 25, then supported mainly by the agricultural sector due to strong crops (soy, corn). Aside from agriculture, the slowdown would be partly explained by adverse financial conditions due to the BCB's latest monetary tightening, higher risk premia caused by fiscal uncertainty and a more-challenging global environment. While we see some downside risks to the Q2 25 print due to a 5% y/y decline in business days in that quarter versus a year earlier (61 versus 64), some offset could come from the release of BRL12bn from a workers' severance fund (FGTS) to up to 12mn workers between March and June. We maintain our annual GDP growth forecast for 2025 at 2.1% (from 3.4% in 2024), considering the support from a tight labor market, rising incomes and various government initiatives that should provide some cushion for domestic demand in H2 despite the ongoing slowdown in credit markets. Among those, we cite the recent launch of revamped, payroll-backed credit lines, the July payment of some BRL63bn (c.0.5% of GDP) in precatories, and a beefed-up housing program ("Minha Casa, Minha Vida").

All authors contributing to this research report are Research Analysts unless otherwise indicated. The publication date at the top of the report reflects the local time where the report was produced and may differ from the release date provided in GMT.

For sectors rated against the Bloomberg U.S. Credit Index, the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index, the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index or the Bloomberg EM USD Corporate and Quasi- Sovereign Index, the analyst expects the six- month excess return of the sector to be in line with the six- month excess return of the relevant index.

For sectors rated against the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Credit Index, the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield 3% Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials, the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield Finance Index or the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Yield Corporate Credit Index, the analyst expects the six- month total return of the sector to be in line with the six- month total return of the relevant index.

For sectors rated against the Bloomberg U.S. Credit Index, the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index, the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index or the Bloomberg EM USD Corporate and Quasi- Sovereign Index, the analyst expects the six- month excess return of the sector to be less than the six- month excess return of the relevant index.

For sectors rated against the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Credit Index, the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield 3% Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials, the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield Finance Index or the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Yield Corporate Credit Index, the analyst expects the six- month total return of the sector to be less than the six- month total return of the relevant index.
Sectors in U.S. High Grade Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg U.S. Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg U.S. Credit Index.

Sectors in U.S. High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg U.S. High Yield 2% Issuer Capped Credit Index.
Sectors in European High Grade Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European Credit Index.

Sectors in Industrials and Utilities in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield 3% Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield 3% Issuer Capped Credit Index excluding Financials.

Sectors in Financials in European High Yield Research are defined using the sector definitions of the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield Finance Index and are rated against the Bloomberg Pan- European High Yield Finance Index.
Sectors in Asia High Grade Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index.
Sectors in Asia High Yield Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Yield Corporate Credit Index.

Sectors in EEMEA and Latin America Research are defined on Barclays Live and are rated against the Bloomberg EM USD Corporate and Quasi Sovereign Index. These sectors may contain both High Grade and High Yield issuers.

Underweight (UW): The analyst expects the six- month total return of the rated debt security subject to this rating to be less than the six- month expected total return of the relevant sector.
Coverage Suspended (CS): Coverage of this issuer has been temporarily suspended.

Not Covered (NC): Barclays' fundamental credit research team does not provide formal, continuous coverage of this issuer and has not assigned a rating to the issuer or its debt securities. Any analysis, opinion or trade recommendation provided on a Not Covered issuer or its debt securities is valid only as of the publication date of this report and there should be no expectation that additional reports relating to the Not Covered issuer or its debt securities will be published thereafter.

Where a recommendation is made at the issuer level, it does not apply to any sanctioned securities, where trading in such securities would be prohibited under applicable law, including sanctions laws and regulations.

\*In EEMEA and Latin America (and in certain other limited instances in other regions), analysts may occasionally rate issuers that are not part of the Bloomberg U.S. Credit Index, the Bloomberg Pan-European Credit Index, the Bloomberg EM Asia USD High Grade Credit Index or Bloomberg EM USD Corporate and Quasi Sovereign Index. In such cases the rating will reflect the analyst's view of the expected excess return over a six- month period of the issuer's corporate debt securities relative to the expected excess return of the relevant sector, as specified on the report.
The analyst expects the six- month excess return of the country's index eligible bonds to exceed the six- month excess return of the Bloomberg EM USD Sovereign Index\*.
The analyst expects the six- month excess return of the country's index eligible bonds to be in line with the six- month excess return of the Bloomberg EM USD Sovereign Index\*.
The analyst expects the six- month excess return of the country's index eligible bonds to be less than the six- month excess return of the Bloomberg EM USD Sovereign Index\*.

\*Analysts may occasionally rate sovereign issuers that are not part of the Bloomberg EM USD Index. In such cases, the rating will still reflect the analyst's view of the expected excess return over a six- month period of the sovereign debt securities relative to the expected excess return of the Bloomberg EM USD Index.

In addition to any ratings assigned under Barclays' formal rating systems, this publication may contain investment recommendations in the form of trade ideas, thematic screens, scorecards or portfolio recommendations that have been produced by analysts in FICC Research. Sustainable Investing Related Research: There is currently no globally accepted framework or definition (legal, regulatory or otherwise) of, nor market consensus as to what constitutes a 'sustainable', 'ESG', 'green', 'climate- friendly' or an equivalent company, investment, strategy or consideration or what precise attributes are required to be eligible to be categorised by such terms. This means there are different ways to evaluate a company or an investment and so different values may be placed on certain sustainability credentials as well as adverse ESG- related impacts of companies and ESG controversies. The evolving nature of sustainable investing considerations, models and methodologies means it can be challenging to definitively and universally classify a company or investment under a sustainable investing label and there may be areas where such companies and investments could improve or where adverse ESG- related impacts or ESG controversies exist. The evolving nature of sustainable finance related regulations and the development of jurisdiction- specific regulatory criteria also means that there is likely to be a degree of divergence as to the interpretation of such terms in the market. We expect industry guidance, market practice, and regulations in this field to continue to evolve.

Any information, data, image, or other content including from a third party source contained, referred to herein or used for whatsoever purpose by Barclays or a third party ("Information"), in relation to any actual or potential 'ESG', 'sustainable' or equivalent objective, issue, factor or consideration is not intended to be relied upon for ESG or sustainability classification, regulatory regime or industry initiative purposes ("ESG Regimes"), unless otherwise stated.
